introduction.title: 🚀 On-Prem Automated Application Deployment: CI/CD Pipeline Setup Using Azure DevOps – A Proof of Concept

introduction.summary: This blog series will walk you through a proof of concept (PoC) implementation of an automated application deployment pipeline on an on-premises server, using a powerful combination of tools including Azure DevOps, GitHub, Docker, and Kubernetes (k3s). For local infrastructure setup, we’ll be leveraging VMware Workstation Pro to provision virtual machines that will simulate a real-world server environment.

introduction.content: Our goal is to build a robust and scalable CI/CD pipeline that can automate the build, test, and deployment of applications on on-prem servers using Azure DevOps. Once we've proven this setup works in an on-premises environment, we will extend the same architecture to Azure Cloud, highlighting how easily DevOps practices can be scaled and migrated.
Here’s a quick snapshot of the tools and technologies we’ll be using throughout this series:

list: Azure DevOps – For CI/CD pipeline management and automation.
Git & GitHub – Version control and source code management.
Docker – Containerizing applications for consistent deployment.
Kubernetes (k3s) – Lightweight Kubernetes distribution for orchestrating deployments.
VMware Workstation Pro – Local VM provisioning to simulate on-prem infrastructure.

introduction.subtitle: 📂 What to Expect in This Series

introduction.content: This is the first in a series of blogs where we will progressively build and refine the CI/CD pipeline. Here's what you can look forward to:

list: Environment Setup – Creating VMs with VMware, installing necessary dependencies.
Source Control Integration – Connecting GitHub repositories with Azure DevOps.
CI Pipeline Implementation – Automating the build and testing process.
Dockerization – Building container images from source code.
CD Pipeline Implementation – Deploying containers to a k3s cluster on-prem.
Monitoring & Logging – Implementing basic observability tools.
Cloud Migration – Replicating the entire setup on Azure Cloud.

introduction.content: A PoC allows us to validate the design and effectiveness of our DevOps approach in a controlled, local environment. It’s a low-risk way to identify gaps, improve configurations, and build confidence before scaling to production or migrating to the cloud.

Whether you're a DevOps engineer looking to explore hybrid deployment strategies or an IT team trying to modernize legacy systems, this series will provide practical insights and step-by-step guidance to build a CI/CD pipeline that works both on-prem and in the cloud.
Stay tuned for the next blog where we'll begin with setting up the on-prem environment and preparing our VMs for deployment.
Let’s automate, orchestrate, and innovate—on-prem first, cloud next!

environment.title: 🛠️ Environment Setup for On-Prem Automated Application Deployment: CI/CD Pipeline with Azure DevOps

environment.summary: To achieve a fully automated application deployment in an on-premise environment using a CI/CD pipeline powered by Azure DevOps, the first step is to set up a reliable and scalable local environment. In this blog post, I’ll walk you through how I configured my setup to support this pipeline. This allows for a seamless DevOps experience—without relying on cloud-hosted infrastructure for core pipeline execution. 🚀

environment.content: Here’s a quick overview of the tools involved:

list: 💻 VMware Workstation Pro – For creating and managing local virtual machines
🔧 Azure DevOps – To manage the CI/CD pipeline
🌐 GitHub – As the centralized version control system
🐳 Docker – For containerizing and running application components
☸️ K3s – Lightweight Kubernetes distribution as the deployment target
🗂️ Git – For source code management on the agent VM

environment.content: To simulate a production-like on-prem environment, I set up two virtual machines (VMs) on VMware Workstation Pro. These VMs serve as the foundation of our DevOps infrastructure:
This VM is the workhorse of the CI/CD pipeline:

list: 🤖 Azure DevOps Agent: Installed and configured as a self-hosted runner to execute pipeline jobs locally.
🐳 Docker: Installed to handle container builds and execution.
🔗 Git: Set up for source control to enable pulling and pushing code as needed.

environment.content: 💡 The agent server runs all major pipeline operations: building, testing, and packaging the app.
This VM acts as the deployment target:

list: ☸️ K3s (Kubernetes lightweight distribution): Installed to simulate a real Kubernetes cluster in an on-prem setup.
📦 This is where the final application is deployed once it’s built and tested by the agent.

environment.content: 💡 K3s gives us a Kubernetes environment with a smaller footprint—perfect for local testing.
Even though the CI/CD process runs locally, the source code is hosted on GitHub:

list: 🔐 Centralized and secure source control
🔄 Integrated with Azure DevOps through service connections
👥 Enables team collaboration and clean version tracking

environment.content: This hybrid approach keeps the pipeline execution local but uses cloud-based GitHub for version management and collaboration.
With this setup, we now have a fully functional on-prem environment ready for automated deployments using Azure DevOps. This configuration:

list: Mimics a real production environment 💼
Offers flexibility and control ⚙️
Reduces reliance on cloud infrastructure 🌍

environment.content: Next up, I’ll guide you through configuring the Azure DevOps pipeline itself—connecting it to the agent, building Docker images, and deploying them to the K3s cluster. 🔧📦🚀
